elements.content: Self-assembly reactions of Pb2+ and L2– (H2L = 4-(5,7-dioxopyrrolo­[3,4-f]­benzimidazol-6-yl)­benzoic acid) lead to two new coordination networks: [Pb3(L)3(H2O)2]·10DMF·6.5H2O (1) is a metal–organic framework (MOF) with a 3D (3,3,8)-connected topology, and [PbL­(DMSO)2] (2) has a 2D nonporous neutral (6,3) honeycomb network. 1 can accommodate a green-emitting neutral dye (fluorescein, FRS) and/or a red-emitting complex cation ([Ru­(bpy)3]2+, [Ru]2+) to form three series of multiemission composites: FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1. Luminescence sensing experiments reveal that 1, B4 (0.017 wt % FRS@1), and G1 (1.261 wt % FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) all show selective luminescence signal changes (emission intensities) toward different volatile organic solvents and nitroaromatic vapors. However, G1 exhibits 2D ratiometric sensing behaviors based on the emission intensity ratios of I MOF/I FRS and I MOF/I [Ru] 2+, which is much more selective and sensitive than the 1D ratiometric (I MOF/I FRS) sensing of B4 and the single-emission sensing of 1. These results reveal that the selectivity of the composite sensors could be well regulated by the incorporation of different luminescent modules, and the sensitivity can be improved by a multidimensional sensing approach.

elements.content:
The selectivity of MOF-based composite sensors can be adjusted by loading different luminescent modules, and the sensitivity can be improved by multidimensional sensing methods.

Introduction

Coordination-assisted self-assembly has been proven to be a powerful strategy to engineer carefully chosen inorganic second building units (SBUs) and multitopic organic linkers into porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with interesting structures and versatile properties. Generally, the nature of the metal ions in inorganic SBUs is essential for the structures and many properties of the resulting MOFs. In comparison with the well-developed transition-metal- or Ln-based MOFs, Pb-MOFs have been much less studied, even though the Pb2+ ion is unique in its stereochemically active lone pair of electrons, special hemi-/holodirected coordination geometries, and varied coordination numbers, all of which indicate that Pb-based MOFs can have diverse structures and fantastic properties.

Introduction

Coordination-assisted self-assembly has been proven to be a powerful strategy to engineer carefully chosen inorganic second building units (SBUs) and multitopic organic linkers into porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with interesting structures and versatile properties. Generally, the nature of the metal ions in inorganic SBUs is essential for the structures and many properties of the resulting MOFs. In comparison with the well-developed transition-metal- or Ln-based MOFs, Pb-MOFs have been much less studied, even though the Pb2+ ion is unique in its stereochemically active lone pair of electrons, special hemi-/holodirected coordination geometries, and varied coordination numbers, all of which indicate that Pb-based MOFs can have diverse structures and fantastic properties.

elements.content: On the other hand, both the inorganic and organic components of MOFs can be used to give rise to luminescence and can further interact to generate metal/ligand charge transfer related luminescence. Coupling luminescence and porosity makes MOFs good candidates for the sensing of cations, anions, small molecular organics, and even biomacromolecules through strong or weak host–analyte interactions. Up to now many MOF sensors have been developed for detecting different analytes, though most of them are based on single-emission luminometry, whose accuracy is limited because the absolute luminescent intensity is very susceptible to many factors such as instability of instrument parameters, background luminescence, etc. In contrast, a self-referencing ratiometric luminescent method can be more accurate, but it generally requires elaborate designs of both ligands and frameworks to control energy transfer between different chromophores in one framework. Recently an alternative approach involving the use of binary composites, either Ln3+@MOFs or dye@MOFs, has been developed. The dichromatic composites can be easily prepared by loading encapsulated luminescent modules (ELMs) into porous MOFs and can be used as one-dimensional (1D) ratiometric sensors that show better sensitivity and selectivity than those based on a single emission. Very recently our work has shown that trichromatic white-light-emitting (WLE) MOF composites, prepared by immobilizing red- and green-emitting iridium/platinum/ruthenium complex cations as ELMs into a porous blue-emitting MOF, can be used as special multidimensional ratiometric luminescent sensors that exhibit sensing performance even better than that of 1D ratiometric sensors. In those studies, the ELM complex cations are based on 2,2′-bipy or 2-phenylpyridine ligands, which can form strong π–π interactions with aromatic analytes; thus, the composites can differentiate aromatic analytes effectively. The research should be greatly extended to ELMs with rich hydrogen-bonding sites so that the sensors may be used to sense analytes that can form strong hydrogen bonds with them. On the other hand, the MOF matrixes used in the studies are anionic. The host frameworks should be greatly extended to the neutral matrixes, considering the fact that there are a large number of reported available neutral MOFs with nanoscale channels.

elements.content: In this study, we first present the synthesis and structures of two new Pb coordination networks, [Pb3(L)3(H2O)2]·10DMF·6.5H2O (1) and [PbL­(DMSO)2] (2), through the reactions of Pb2+ and H2L (H2L = 4-(5,7-dioxopyrrolo­[3,4-f]­benzimidazol-6-yl)­benzoic acid, DMF = dimethylformamide). Postsynthetic immobilization experiments show that a neutral dye (fluorescein, FRS) with phenolic and carbonyl groups and/or a complex cation ([Ru­(bpy)3]2+, [Ru]2+) can be loaded into nanoporous 1 to form three composites: FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1, among which G1 (1.261 wt % FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) emits white light with CIE coordinates of (0.33, 0.34). Sensing experiments reveal that 1, B4 (0.014 wt % FRS@1), and G1 all show luminescence signal changes toward different volatile organic solvents (VOSs) and nitroaromatic (NAC) vapors, while the 2D ratiometric sensor G1 is the most selective and sensitive among them. Interestingly, G1 shows a visible color change when it is contacted with DMSO (blue), DMF (red), and DMA (blue) with white as the starting point, indicating that the use of FRS with rich hydrogen bonding sites as an ELM can increases the WLE sensor’s ability to distinguish analytes that can form strong hydrogen bonds. Details of their crystal structures, immobilization, and sensing properties are discussed.

Details of their crystal structures, immobilization, and sensing properties are discussed.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monolinic P21/c space group and has a 3D framework based on trinuclear {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBUs and L2– ligands. A summary of the most important crystal and structure refinement data is given in Table S1. As shown in , the three Pb2+ ions all have hemidirected geometries and the corresponding donor sets are very distorted tetrahedral {O2N2} and monocapped pyramidal {O4N2} and {O3N2}, respectively (Figure S1). The three Pb­(II) ions are bridged by three imidazole groups to form a triangular metal skeleton with Pb···Pb separations in the range of 6.56–6.92 Å. In addition, Pb1 and Pb2 are each further coordinated to a carboxylate group, in either a monodentate or chelate fashion. In contrast, Pb3 is further coordinated by two monodentate and one chelate carboxylate group. Thus, an unusual {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBU is formed. As the five carboxylate and three imidazole groups are from eight ligands, the SBU can be treated as an 8-connected node. Three independent ligands are observed in the structure. As shown in Figure S2, their coordination modes are μ3-κN 1:κN 1:κO 2, μ4-κN 1: κN 1:κO 2:κO 1, and μ4-κN 1:κN 1:κO 1:κO 1 respectively. All of them can be treated as 3-connected nodes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures of 1 and 2 

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monolinic P21/c space group and has a 3D framework based on trinuclear {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBUs and L2- ligands. A summary of the most important crystal and structure refinement data is given in Table S1. As shown in , the three Pb2+ ions all have hemidirected geometries and the corresponding donor sets are very distorted tetrahedral {O2N2} and monocapped pyramidal {O4N2} and {O3N2}, respectively (Figure S1). The three Pb(II) ions are bridged by three imidazole groups to form a triangular metal skeleton with Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb separations in the range of 6.56-6.92 Å. In addition, Pb1 and Pb2 are each further coordinated to a carboxylate group, in either a monodentate or chelate fashion. In contrast, Pb3 is further coordinated by two monodentate and one chelate carboxylate group. Thus, an unusual {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBU is formed. As the five carboxylate and three imidazole groups are from eight ligands, the SBU can be treated as an 8-connected node. Three independent ligands are observed in the structure. As shown in Figure S2, their coordination modes are μ3-κN 1:κN 1:κO 2, μ4-κN 1: κN 1:κO 2:κO 1, and μ4-κN 1:κN 1:κO 1:κO 1 respectively. All of them can be treated as 3-connected nodes.

elements.content: Structure of 1. (a) Structure of the­{Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBU. Symmetry codes: (A) 3 – x, 1 – y, 2 – z; (B) x – 1, 3/2 – y, −1/2 + z; (C) 3 – x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 – z. (b) Packing of the framework viewed along the c direction. (c) Structure of the quasi-rodlike backbone bridged by both carboxylate and imidazole groups.

(b) Packing of the framework viewed along the c direction. (c) Structure of the quasi-rodlike backbone bridged by both carboxylate and imidazole groups.

elements.content: The combination of the 8-connected {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBUs and the 3-connected ligands leads to a 3D neutral network with a new (3,3,8)-connected topology, as revealed by TOPOS calculations. The corresponding Schlafli symbol is {3; 4; 5}­{42; 6}­{32; 43; 56; 610; 74; 83} (see Figure S3). The framework exhibits 26 × 14 Å2 rhombus channels along the c crystallographic direction. Disordered solvent molecules are located in these channels. The solvent-accessible volume of 1 without guest molecules, calculated by PLATON, is about 47.1% of the unit cell volume.

The corresponding Schlafli symbol is {3; 4; 5}{42; 6}{32; 43; 56; 610; 74; 83} (see Figure S3). The framework exhibits 26 × 14 Å2 rhombus channels along the c crystallographic direction. Disordered solvent molecules are located in these channels. The solvent-accessible volume of 1 without guest molecules, calculated by PLATON, is about 47.1% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: The framework is further stabilized by abundant π–π interactions. As shown in Figure S4, the neighboring ligands (N3 and N6) are packed in such a close mode that strong offset face-to-face π–π interactions are formed between contiguous benzimidazole rings with ring–ring separations (center to center) in the range of 3.54–3.94 Å. In addition, edge-to-face and offset face-to-face π–π interactions are formed consecutively between the neighboring benzene rings. Thus, interesting π–π interaction triple chains running along the c direction are formed. Furthermore, neighboring third types of ligands (N9 and N9F) are dimerized through the carbonyl–benzene π–π interactions and the corresponding separation is 3.40 Å.
elements.clean_text: The framework is further stabilized by abundant π-π interactions. As shown in Figure S4, the neighboring ligands (N3 and N6) are packed in such a close mode that strong offset face-to-face π-π interactions are formed between contiguous benzimidazole rings with ring-ring separations (center to center) in the range of 3.54-3.94 Å. In addition, edge-to-face and offset face-to-face π-π interactions are formed consecutively between the neighboring benzene rings. Thus, interesting π-π interaction triple chains running along the c direction are formed. Furthermore, neighboring third types of ligands (N9 and N9F) are dimerized through the carbonyl-benzene π-π interactions and the corresponding separation is 3.40 Å.

elements.content: Another interesting feature of the framework is its quasi-rodlike backbone. Unlike the common rodlike structure only bridged by carboxylate groups, here the backbone is bridged by both carboxylate and imidazole groups, which leads to a special double-chain metal skeleton, as shown in c. In addition, the utilization of imidazole groups to construct the backbone can increase the Pb···Pb separations effectively (the separations of Pb2+ ions bridged by carboxylate groups are in the range 3.88–4.19 Å, in comparison with 6.56–6.92 Å for those bridged by imidazole groups), which can lead to a high porosity and large channel size. Similar to the role of the reported rodlike backbone, here the quasi-rodlike backbone can also inhibit interpenetration.

Similar to the role of the reported rodlike backbone, here the quasi-rodlike backbone can also inhibit interpenetration.

elements.content: 2 also crystallizes in the P21/c space group but features a 2D neutral (6,3) network based on {Pb­(im)2(COO)} SBUs and L2‑ ligands (). Figure S5 shows the coordination environment of the only independent Pb2+ ion with a distorted-octahedral coordination polyhedron. The related {Pb­(im)2(COO)} SBU can be treated as a 3-connected node. Each ligand adopts a μ3-κN 1:κN 1:κO 2 coordination mode and uses its imidazole and carboxylate functional groups to coordinate to three metal ions that belong to three {Pb­(im)2(COO)} SBUs and can also be treated as a 3-connected node. The combination of the two types of nodes in a 1:1 ratio gives rise to a neutral 2D (6,3) net perpendicular to the b direction (Figure S6). The packing of the framework along the b direction is shown in Figure S7.

elements.content: The purity and crystallinity of the bulk samples of 1 and 2 were confirmed by a powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figure S8). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) under an N2 atmosphere was used to study their thermal stabilities. The thermal behavior of 1 (Figure S12) involves the loss of all the free H2O and 3.5 DMF solvent molecules before 277 °C (experimental, 15.38%; calculated, 15.40%). In the second step it loses 2 DMF solvent molecules until 442 °C (experimental, 6.47%; calculated, 6.04%). Then the compound continues to lose weight until complete decomposition of the structure. The first step (17.23%) of weight loss of 2 occurs at temperatures below 327 °C and is assigned to the loss of 1.5 coordinated DMSO solvent molecules (calculated, 17.53%). Then there is a plateau in the temperature range 327–425 °C. After 425 °C 2 shows a striking weight loss, indicating the complete decomposition of the structure.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence spectra of H2L, 1, and 2 (λex = 365 nm) were collected at room temperature (Figure S13). An intense emission peak at 467 nm is observed in the emission spectrum of H2L. In contrast, 1 and 2 exhibit obvious blue shifts with strong peaks at 452 and 434 nm, respectively, both of which can also be attributed to a linker-localized transition. The different emission blue shifts may be attributed to the different configurations and coordination modes of the ligands in the compounds. The CIE coordinates for the blue emission of 1 and 2 were calculated to be (0.17, 0.17) and (0.17, 0.14), close to those of a saturated blue emitter (0.14, 0.08).

elements.content: Both the large porous channels (25.9 Å × 11.6 Å) and stabilities in organic solvents make 1 an excellent candidate for the host material. Loading experiments show that two ELMs, the distorted-tetrahedral green-emitting FRS with a size of ∼10 × 8 Å (emission colors are yellow and green in high- and low-concentration solutions, respectively) and spherical red-emitting [Ru]2+ with s diameter of ∼12 Å (structures are shown in Figure S14, and emission spectra are shown in Figures S15 and S16), can be captured into the channels of 1 simultaneously or separately to produce three series of composites: FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 with different concentrations of FRS/[Ru]2+. The loading amounts of the ELMs are feasibly controllable by varying the concentrations of the initial solution, and the exact amount is established by luminescent measurements of the filtrate (Figures S17 and S18). The original framework is maintained in all the resulting composites, as revealed by PXRD (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Preparations of the Binary/Ternary Composites FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 

Both the large porous channels (25.9 Å × 11.6 Å) and stabilities in organic solvents make 1 an excellent candidate for the host material. Loading experiments show that two ELMs, the distorted-tetrahedral green-emitting FRS with a size of ~10 × 8 Å (emission colors are yellow and green in high- and low-concentration solutions, respectively) and spherical red-emitting [Ru]2+ with s diameter of ~12 Å (structures are shown in Figure S14, and emission spectra are shown in Figures S15 and S16), can be captured into the channels of 1 simultaneously or separately to produce three series of composites: FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 with different concentrations of FRS/[Ru]2+. The loading amounts of the ELMs are feasibly controllable by varying the concentrations of the initial solution, and the exact amount is established by luminescent measurements of the filtrate (Figures S17 and S18). The original framework is maintained in all the resulting composites, as revealed by PXRD (Figure S9).

elements.content: The emission spectra of thoroughly ground mixtures of FRS+1 and [Ru]2++1 (both with weight ratios of 1:50) were measured (λex = 365 nm). As shown in Figure S19, the two finely ground mixtures only present the emission band of solely compound 1, whereas both FRS@1 and [Ru]2+@1 binary composites display two emission peaks of the framework and ELM. Furthermore, an obvious color change from colorless to gray and orange-red could be observed respectively for the resulting FRS@1 and [Ru]2+@1 solid samples, respectively (Figure S20). Similar soaking experiments of 2 built from the same ligand and metal ions as those of 1 but with a nonporous structure were also performed (Figure S21). The resulting samples do not display any emission related to FRS and [Ru]2+, clearly indicating the two ELMs cannot just be absorbed on the outside surface of the crystals. All of the results indicate a successful encapsulation of the FRS/[Ru]2+ guests into the channels of 1.

elements.content: In order to check whether the loaded FRS/[Ru]2+ ELMs can leak out from the framework, resoaking experiments were performed by exposing the composites into MeOH for 24 h. No obvious emission band attributable to FRS/[Ru]2+ was observed in the luminescent spectra of the filtrate (Figure S22), indicating the weak interactions between the FRS/[Ru]2+ ELMs and the framework are strong enough so that the ELMs cannot escape from the framework.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S23, the peaks of both the framework and FRS are observed in FRS@1. Upon an increase in the concentration of FRS in the FRS@1 composite, the dye-based emission peak shows an obvious red shift (from 522 to 558 nm), accompanied by an increase in intensity. At the same time, the emission peak of the framework decreases and blue-shifts. Both the peak shifts and changes in emission peak intensity indicate excitation energy transfer from the framework to guests. Such an efficient resonance energy transfer was also evidenced by the spectral overlap between the FRS absorption and 1 emission spectra (Figure S25). Similar results are also observed in the solid-state emission spectra of [Ru]2+@1 (Figure S24). One interesting difference between FRS@1 and [Ru]2+@1 is the loading amounts of the ELMs. In FRS@1, the loading amount of the FRS can be adjusted over a large range and the luminescence colors of the resulting composites can be tuned from blue to green and then yellow. In contrast, the loading amount of [Ru]2+ is less adjustable. As shown in Figure S24, the strongest red emission intensity is observed in Q4 (0.620 wt % [Ru]2+@1) with the smallest I MOF/I [Ru] 2+ value among all the [Ru]2+@1 composites. Further increasing the concentration of the soaked [Ru]­(PF6)2 solution only leads to a slight increase in the loaded [Ru]2+ guest and the maximum load capacity is 0.655 wt % (Q3), accompanied by a slight decrease of the red emission intensity, which can be explained by the concentration quenching effect. Such a low saturated load capacity in the cationic ELM@neutral framework immobilization of [Ru]2+@1 is quite different from that of the neutral ELM@neutral framework immobilization of FRS@1 and the reported cationic ELM@anionic framework immobilizations and can be explained as strong electrostatic repulsion between the loaded [Ru]2+ ELMs while the neutral framework is not helpful in reducing the repulsion.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure S23, the peaks of both the framework and FRS are observed in FRS@1. Upon an increase in the concentration of FRS in the FRS@1 composite, the dye-based emission peak shows an obvious red shift (from 522 to 558 nm), accompanied by an increase in intensity. At the same time, the emission peak of the framework decreases and blue-shifts. Both the peak shifts and changes in emission peak intensity indicate excitation energy transfer from the framework to guests. Such an efficient resonance energy transfer was also evidenced by the spectral overlap between the FRS absorption and 1 emission spectra (Figure S25). Similar results are also observed in the solid-state emission spectra of [Ru]2+@1 (Figure S24). One interesting difference between FRS@1 and [Ru]2+@1 is the loading amounts of the ELMs. In FRS@1, the loading amount of the FRS can be adjusted over a large range and the luminescence colors of the resulting composites can be tuned from blue to green and then yellow. In contrast, the loading amount of [Ru]2+ is less adjustable. As shown in Figure S24, the strongest red emission intensity is observed in Q4 (0.620 wt % [Ru]2+@1) with the smallest I MOF/I [Ru] 2+ value among all the [Ru]2+@1 composites. Further increasing the concentration of the soaked [Ru](PF6)2 solution only leads to a slight increase in the loaded [Ru]2+ guest and the maximum load capacity is 0.655 wt % (Q3), accompanied by a slight decrease of the red emission intensity, which can be explained by the concentration quenching effect. Such a low saturated load capacity in the cationic ELM@neutral framework immobilization of [Ru]2+@1 is quite different from that of the neutral ELM@neutral framework immobilization of FRS@1 and the reported cationic ELM@anionic framework immobilizations and can be explained as strong electrostatic repulsion between the loaded [Ru]2+ ELMs while the neutral framework is not helpful in reducing the repulsion.

elements.content: A further trapping attempt indicates that FRS and [Ru]2+ ELMs could be captured simultaneously into the channels of 1 by soaking 1 into a solution containing FRS + [Ru]2+ (). The WLE composite can be prepared by controlling the encapsulated amount of the two types of ELMs through adjusting their concentrations. Several ratios were tried, and the best ratio is that for G1 (1.261 wt % FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1), which displays a broad-band emission covering the whole visible spectral region with three main peaks at 457, 534, and 588 nm, respectively. The corresponding CIE coordinates are (0.33, 0.34), which is very close to pure WLE CIE coordinates (0.33, 0.33).

elements.content: Since 1, FRS@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 composites are all stable in various VOSs, their sensing behaviors for various VOSs were investigated. Finely ground samples of them were dispersed in 10 common solvents (MeOH, EtOH, acetone, MeCN, ethyl acetate (EA), hexane, cyclohexane (Cyclo), DMF, DMA, and DMSO) and four aromatic solvents (benzene (Ben), fluorobenzene (F-Ben), chlorobenzene (Cl-Ben), and bromobenzene (Br-Ben)) to form emulsions for luminescence studies. As shown in , both the peak shifts and the intensities of 1 in the emission spectra excited at 365 nm are dependent on the solvent. In comparison with that in the solid state, the peak in MeOH is slightly red shifted (457 nm). In contrast, the peaks in all other solvents are more or less blue shifted, particularly for Br-Ben, which exhibits the largest red-shifted value (∼14 nm). From an intensity point of view, three solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and DMSO) show outstanding enhancement effects, while hexane exhibits the most significant quenching effect. However, under 365 nm UV light illumination, only the hexane suspension has an obviously darkened luminescence and can be clearly differentiated by the naked eye, as shown in c.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Sensing of VOSs

Since 1, FRS@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 composites are all stable in various VOSs, their sensing behaviors for various VOSs were investigated. Finely ground samples of them were dispersed in 10 common solvents (MeOH, EtOH, acetone, MeCN, ethyl acetate (EA), hexane, cyclohexane (Cyclo), DMF, DMA, and DMSO) and four aromatic solvents (benzene (Ben), fluorobenzene (F-Ben), chlorobenzene (Cl-Ben), and bromobenzene (Br-Ben)) to form emulsions for luminescence studies. As shown in , both the peak shifts and the intensities of 1 in the emission spectra excited at 365 nm are dependent on the solvent. In comparison with that in the solid state, the peak in MeOH is slightly red shifted (457 nm). In contrast, the peaks in all other solvents are more or less blue shifted, particularly for Br-Ben, which exhibits the largest red-shifted value (~14 nm). From an intensity point of view, three solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and DMSO) show outstanding enhancement effects, while hexane exhibits the most significant quenching effect. However, under 365 nm UV light illumination, only the hexane suspension has an obviously darkened luminescence and can be clearly differentiated by the naked eye, as shown in c.

elements.content: Emission spectra (a), the corresponding emission intensities (b), and photographic images (c) of the emulsions of 1 in different solvents under UV light illumination (365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 4  Emission spectra (a), the corresponding emission intensities (b), and photographic images (c) of the emulsions of 1 in different solvents under UV light illumination (365 nm).

elements.content: a shows the emission spectra of B4 (0.014 wt % FRS@1) in various VOSs. Obviously, the green emission intensities of the composite in DMA and DMSO are greatly weakened. In contrast, both the peak shifts and the intensities of the two emissions in other solvents only show nonspecific changes. However, for each solvent, the emission peak height ratio of MOF to ELM (I MOF/I FRS) is almost fixed and can be easily correlated with the solvent molecule. Such a selective solvent-responsive change in ratiometric luminescence can be attributed to the adjustment of the energy transfer efficiency from the MOF to the ELM by the different solvent molecules trapped in the MOF channel. In DMA and DMSO cases, ELM leakage from the composite into the two solvents is suggested to be the main reason for the sensor’s special luminescence behavior (Figure S22). The interesting sensing behaviors can be further used for 1D code recognition of solvents based on the emission peak height ratio. In comparison with the above luminescent measurement based on a single emission, such a self-referencing ratiometric luminescence method has the ability to overcome errors caused by optical occlusion, concentration inhomogeneities, excitation power fluctuations, or environment-induced nonradiative relaxation during the measurement. Thus, it is more accurate and reliable. Using this method, DMA, DMSO, DMF, and MeOH with I MOF/I FRS values of 2.53, 2.19, 1.19, and 0.72, respectively, can be undoubtedly recognized. However, for the other 10 VOSs, the values are in the range of 1.03–0.85 and the difference between them is less than 0.1. Even a ratiometric luminescence method cannot be used to differentiate them. Interestingly, under illumination at 365 nm, B4 changed to blue upon exposure to DMA and DMSO, while it was green upon exposure to other VOSs. Therefore, B4 is a sensitive luminescent sensor that can enable the detection of DMA and DMSO that is visible to the naked eye.

elements.content: Remarkably the WLE G1 (1.261 wt % FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) composite can act as a special dual-ratiometric luminescence sensor to recognize the VOSs through a 2D orthogonal emission-fingerprint map of VOSs based on the emission peak height ratios of MOFs to ELMs (I MOF/I FRS and I MOF/I [Ru] 2+). As shown in a, the emission spectra of G1 in various VOSs also show some nonspecific changes, but the two ratios are almost fixed for each VOS and can be correlated to the molecules included (b). Such a selective solvent-responsive change can also be explained by the same reason as that in the 1D ratiometric sensor. Obviously the resulting 2D coded map is also self-referencing but is more accurate and reliable than that of the 1D sensor due to its ability to double the output information. Using this method, a large majority of VOSs can be undoubtedly recognized except for Ben (0.948, 1.473), F-Ben (0.944, 1.329), and Cl-Ben (0.952, 1.405) with close readouts. In comparison with our previous reported trichromatic WLE sensor based on luminescent ELMs that can differentiate aromatic analytes effectively, the use of FRS with rich hydrogen-bonding sites reduces G1’s ability to distinguish aromatic analytes but increases its ability to distinguish analytes that can form hydrogen bonds, as observed in the distinctive readouts of DMF (1.934, 1.084) and MeOH (0.920, 2.350).
elements.clean_text: Remarkably the WLE G1 (1.261 wt % FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) composite can act as a special dual-ratiometric luminescence sensor to recognize the VOSs through a 2D orthogonal emission-fingerprint map of VOSs based on the emission peak height ratios of MOFs to ELMs (I MOF/I FRS and I MOF/I [Ru] 2+). As shown in a, the emission spectra of G1 in various VOSs also show some nonspecific changes, but the two ratios are almost fixed for each VOS and can be correlated to the molecules included (b). Such a selective solvent-responsive change can also be explained by the same reason as that in the 1D ratiometric sensor. Obviously the resulting 2D coded map is also self-referencing but is more accurate and reliable than that of the 1D sensor due to its ability to double the output information. Using this method, a large majority of VOSs can be undoubtedly recognized except for Ben (0.948, 1.473), F-Ben (0.944, 1.329), and Cl-Ben (0.952, 1.405) with close readouts. In comparison with our previous reported trichromatic WLE sensor based on luminescent ELMs that can differentiate aromatic analytes effectively, the use of FRS with rich hydrogen-bonding sites reduces G1's ability to distinguish aromatic analytes but increases its ability to distinguish analytes that can form hydrogen bonds, as observed in the distinctive readouts of DMF (1.934, 1.084) and MeOH (0.920, 2.350).

elements.clean_text: 6  Emission spectra (a), the corresponding 2D code map based on ratiometric intensities, (b) and photographic images (c) of the emulsions of G1 in different solvents under UV light illumination (365 nm).

elements.content: Moreover, when it is exposed to DMF, G1 shows dramatic color changes (from white to brown) under UV light irradiation (365 nm) due to a larger MOF to [Ru]2+ emission peak height ratio change (from 0.91 to 1.93), indicating that G1 is an excellent sensor for DMF (Figure S26). In contrast, G1 exhibits a relatively blue emitting color in DMA and DMSO suspensions. Unlike other luminescent color change MOF sensors based on strong donor–acceptor interactions, which sometimes even involve charge transfer (CT) or exciplex/excimer formation and always require an elaborate design of both the ligand and the framework, here the luminescent color change of G1 is caused by tuning the emission peak height ratios and/or leaking of the ELMs. Such a strategy is obviously simple and easy to accomplish through just assembly of a three-chromophore MOF composite. Furthermore, the three-chromophore WLE nature of G1 causes the color contrast before and after the color change process to be strong, which is conducive to observation by the naked eye.

In contrast, G1 exhibits a relatively blue emitting color in DMA and DMSO suspensions. Unlike other luminescent color change MOF sensors based on strong donor-acceptor interactions, which sometimes even involve charge transfer (CT) or exciplex/excimer formation and always require an elaborate design of both the ligand and the framework, here the luminescent color change of G1 is caused by tuning the emission peak height ratios and/or leaking of the ELMs. Such a strategy is obviously simple and easy to accomplish through just assembly of a three-chromophore MOF composite. Furthermore, the three-chromophore WLE nature of G1 causes the color contrast before and after the color change process to be strong, which is conducive to observation by the naked eye.

elements.content: We also investigated the sensing behaviors of 1, B4, and G1 composites toward NAC vapors by monitoring the changes in luminescent spectra of thin-layer samples before and immediately after exposure to the equilibrated vapors of different NACs at three temperatures (25, 40, and 60 °C). The quenching efficiency (percent) was estimated using the formula [(I 0 – I)/I 0] × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the exposure to NAC vapors, respectively. The time-dependent emission spectra, the corresponding quenching efficiencies, and a summary of the quenching efficiencies at 15 min of 1 upon exposure to NAC vapors are shown in Figures S27–S29 and respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Sensing of NAC Vapors

We also investigated the sensing behaviors of 1, B4, and G1 composites toward NAC vapors by monitoring the changes in luminescent spectra of thin-layer samples before and immediately after exposure to the equilibrated vapors of different NACs at three temperatures (25, 40, and 60 °C). The quenching efficiency (percent) was estimated using the formula [(I 0 - I)/I 0] × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the exposure to NAC vapors, respectively. The time-dependent emission spectra, the corresponding quenching efficiencies, and a summary of the quenching efficiencies at 15 min of 1 upon exposure to NAC vapors are shown in Figures S27-S29 and  respectively.

At 25 °C, among the 15 investigated NACs, only the vapors of 3-NPHEN and p-DNB have no quenching effect; In contrast, the other 13 NACs can quench the emission peak of 1. Since control experiments of nonporous 2 that is made up of the same ligand and metal ion under the same conditions show that the emission of 2 cannot be quenched by any NAC vapors, the quenching of the emission of 1 should take place inside its rhombus channels. In addition, the broad-range detection ability of 1 toward NAC vapors in comparison with reported MOF-based sensors could be due to the fact that the size of the channels is large enough for the different NAC molecules to enter.

elements.content: When the sensing temperature is increased to 40 and 60 °C, the quenching efficiencies of all the NACs increased accordingly. Even the vapors of 3-NPHEN and p-DNB can quench the emission of 1. The reason could be due to the fact that a higher temperature induces higher vapor pressures of the NACs. Among all of the investigated NACs, 2-NPHEN has the largest quenching efficiency (up to 90% at 15 min and 60 °C) and quickest response time (in 30 s the quenching efficiency is up to 56.7% at 25 °C), both of which are quite different from those of other NACs, indicating that 1 can be used to selectively recognize 2-NPHEN. The unusual quenching behavior of 2-NPHEN could be due to its easy sublimation induced by intramolecular hydrogen bonding. According to the literature, the quenching of 1 by the NACs can be clarified as the result of several points, including MOF to NAC electron transfer, as evidenced by a comparison of the HOMOs and LUMOs of H2L and all the NACs calculated through density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP/6-31G* level (Figure S30A), MOF to NAC resonance energy transfer, as established by the spectral overlap between the emission spectrum of 1 and the absorption spectra of some NACs (Figure S30B), weak supramolecular interactions between the ligands and NACs, etc.

elements.content: The quenching behavior of B4 was also investigated, and the results are shown in Figures S31 and S32. Although there are a few exceptions, the main trend is the quenching efficiencies of NACs toward the framework and FRS ELM are lower than those of 1, which can be explained by the blocking of the channels by the ELMs after the formation of the composite. For some NACs (o-DNB, m-DNB, p-DNB, 1-NP, 4-NBB, 3-NPHEN, and 4-NPHEN), their molecular size is too large so that they cannot enter the channels of B4 and quench its luminescence at 25 °C, though they can quench the luminescence of 1 under the same conditions. From another perspective, the loading of FRS ELMs into the channels of 1 can be viewed as a decoration of the channels, which can increase the selectivity of the channels toward NAC molecules. However, the selectivity can be removed through an increase in temperature (vapor concentration increase), as confirmed by the quenching at higher temperature (40 and 60 °C).

elements.content: An NAC molecule can quench the two emission peaks of B4 to different degrees. and Figure S33 show the time-dependent evolution of the I MOF/I FRS ratio during the NAC vapor sensing processes. According to whether the values of I MOF/I FRS become larger or smaller than the initial value, the quenching behaviors can be divided into two categories. For o-DNB, 2-NPHEN, and DNBP, the related I MOF/I FRS values decrease with an increase in time, showing that they can more effectively quench the luminescence of the framework. For other NACs, the opposite results are observed. The aforementioned 1D code recognition method based on I MOF/I FRS values can also be used to differentiate different NAC vapors. However, the trajectories of most of the NACs are overlapping, and only the trajectory of 2-NPHEN is clearly distinguished from those of other NACs at 25 °C, indicating that 2-NPHEN can be recognized by the method. Note that, although all of the NAC I MOF/I FRS values keep changing during the sensing processes, the changes cannot cause a noticeable change in luminescence color.

elements.content: The NAC vapor sensing experiments of G1 shows that at 25 and 40 °C all of the NAC vapors did not exhibit any quenching effect to the luminescence of G1, and at 60 °C only vapors of NB and o-DNB can quench the emission peaks of G1 (Figure S34). Due to the different quenching rates of the three emission peaks, the ratios of I MOF/I FRS and I MOF/I [Ru] 2+ keep changing during the sensing process for the two NACs. As illustrated in a, in 1 min the ratios change from the origin (1.06, 0.91) to (1.24, 1.14) for NB and (1.12, 0.96) for o-DNB, respectively. The separation of the two points is up to 0.22, large enough to differentiate the two NACs. In the subsequent sensing stage the two sets of data points move into totally different regions, which further increases the discriminability between the two NACs. Thus, a 2D dynamic code map is established and can be used to differentiate the NACs on the basis of the different tracks of the ratios in the 2D plane. When time is added as the third dimension, a 3D code recognition in which the difference between the two sets of data points is further amplified can be obtained and is more helpful in distinguishing them (b). Obviously, in comparison with the above sensors based on single or dual emissions which generally cannot be used to differentiate a series of NACs with similar structures and luminescence changes, G1 is a multidimensional sensor with excellent amplified ability, and thus better sensitivity and selectivity and can accomplish the tasks. However, no noticeable change in luminescence color can be observed. Such results also that indicate the selectivity of the MOF-based composites toward the sensing of NAC vapors can be further improved by adjusting the amount and type of the ELMs.

elements.content: In summary, two new Pb coordination networks (1 and 2) based on a imidazolate-/carboxylate-functionalized ligand have been successfully prepared. The neutral nanoporous framework of 1 has a new (3,3,8)-connected network. Three series of binary/ternary composites, FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1, can be prepared by incorporating one or two types of ELMs (either a neutral dye or a complex cation) into the channels of 1. 1, B4 (0.014 wt % FRS@1) and G1 (1.261 wt %FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) can sense VOSs and NAC vapors through single-emission sensing, 1D ratiometric sensing, and high-dimensional (2D and 3D) ratiometric sensing approaches, respectively. In addition, G1 can differentiate vapors of NB and o-DNB in 1 min. The study not only demonstrates that neutral porous MOFs can also be utilized to construct multidimensional ratiometric sensors, which greatly expands the choice of MOF matrixes, but also shows that the selectivity and sensitivity of the sensors can be regulated by incorporating different ELMs. Research efforts on new MOF composite-based sensors with high selectivity for special analytes are ongoing in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two new Pb coordination networks (1 and 2) based on a imidazolate-/carboxylate-functionalized ligand have been successfully prepared. The neutral nanoporous framework of 1 has a new (3,3,8)-connected network. Three series of binary/ternary composites, FRS@1, [Ru]2+@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1, can be prepared by incorporating one or two types of ELMs (either a neutral dye or a complex cation) into the channels of 1. 1, B4 (0.014 wt % FRS@1) and G1 (1.261 wt %FRS + 0.463 wt % [Ru]2+@1) can sense VOSs and NAC vapors through single-emission sensing, 1D ratiometric sensing, and high-dimensional (2D and 3D) ratiometric sensing approaches, respectively. In addition, G1 can differentiate vapors of NB and o-DNB in 1 min. The study not only demonstrates that neutral porous MOFs can also be utilized to construct multidimensional ratiometric sensors, which greatly expands the choice of MOF matrixes, but also shows that the selectivity and sensitivity of the sensors can be regulated by incorporating different ELMs. Research efforts on new MOF composite-based sensors with high selectivity for special analytes are ongoing in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the monolinic P21/c space group and has a 3D framework based on trinuclear {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBUs and L2– ligands. A summary of the most important crystal and structure refinement data is given in Table S1. As shown in , the three Pb2+ ions all have hemidirected geometries and the corresponding donor sets are very distorted tetrahedral {O2N2} and monocapped pyramidal {O4N2} and {O3N2}, respectively (Figure S1). The three Pb­(II) ions are bridged by three imidazole groups to form a triangular metal skeleton with Pb···Pb separations in the range of 6.56–6.92 Å. In addition, Pb1 and Pb2 are each further coordinated to a carboxylate group, in either a monodentate or chelate fashion. In contrast, Pb3 is further coordinated by two monodentate and one chelate carboxylate group. Thus, an unusual {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBU is formed. As the five carboxylate and three imidazole groups are from eight ligands, the SBU can be treated as an 8-connected node. Three independent ligands are observed in the structure. As shown in Figure S2, their coordination modes are μ3-κN 1:κN 1:κO 2, μ4-κN 1: κN 1:κO 2:κO 1, and μ4-κN 1:κN 1:κO 1:κO 1 respectively. All of them can be treated as 3-connected nodes.

The combination of the 8-connected {Pb3(im)3(COO)5} SBUs and the 3-connected ligands leads to a 3D neutral network with a new (3,3,8)-connected topology, as revealed by TOPOS calculations. The corresponding Schlafli symbol is {3; 4; 5}­{42; 6}­{32; 43; 56; 610; 74; 83} (see Figure S3). The framework exhibits 26 × 14 Å2 rhombus channels along the c crystallographic direction. Disordered solvent molecules are located in these channels. The solvent-accessible volume of 1 without guest molecules, calculated by PLATON, is about 47.1% of the unit cell volume.

The purity and crystallinity of the bulk samples of 1 and 2 were confirmed by a powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figure S8). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) under an N2 atmosphere was used to study their thermal stabilities. The thermal behavior of 1 (Figure S12) involves the loss of all the free H2O and 3.5 DMF solvent molecules before 277 °C (experimental, 15.38%; calculated, 15.40%). In the second step it loses 2 DMF solvent molecules until 442 °C (experimental, 6.47%; calculated, 6.04%). Then the compound continues to lose weight until complete decomposition of the structure. The first step (17.23%) of weight loss of 2 occurs at temperatures below 327 °C and is assigned to the loss of 1.5 coordinated DMSO solvent molecules (calculated, 17.53%). Then there is a plateau in the temperature range 327–425 °C. After 425 °C 2 shows a striking weight loss, indicating the complete decomposition of the structure.

The solid-state luminescence spectra of H2L, 1, and 2 (λex = 365 nm) were collected at room temperature (Figure S13). An intense emission peak at 467 nm is observed in the emission spectrum of H2L. In contrast, 1 and 2 exhibit obvious blue shifts with strong peaks at 452 and 434 nm, respectively, both of which can also be attributed to a linker-localized transition. The different emission blue shifts may be attributed to the different configurations and coordination modes of the ligands in the compounds. The CIE coordinates for the blue emission of 1 and 2 were calculated to be (0.17, 0.17) and (0.17, 0.14), close to those of a saturated blue emitter (0.14, 0.08).

As shown in Figure S23, the peaks of both the framework and FRS are observed in FRS@1. Upon an increase in the concentration of FRS in the FRS@1 composite, the dye-based emission peak shows an obvious red shift (from 522 to 558 nm), accompanied by an increase in intensity. At the same time, the emission peak of the framework decreases and blue-shifts. Both the peak shifts and changes in emission peak intensity indicate excitation energy transfer from the framework to guests. Such an efficient resonance energy transfer was also evidenced by the spectral overlap between the FRS absorption and 1 emission spectra (Figure S25). Similar results are also observed in the solid-state emission spectra of [Ru]2+@1 (Figure S24). One interesting difference between FRS@1 and [Ru]2+@1 is the loading amounts of the ELMs. In FRS@1, the loading amount of the FRS can be adjusted over a large range and the luminescence colors of the resulting composites can be tuned from blue to green and then yellow. In contrast, the loading amount of [Ru]2+ is less adjustable. As shown in Figure S24, the strongest red emission intensity is observed in Q4 (0.620 wt % [Ru]2+@1) with the smallest I MOF/I [Ru] 2+ value among all the [Ru]2+@1 composites. Further increasing the concentration of the soaked [Ru]­(PF6)2 solution only leads to a slight increase in the loaded [Ru]2+ guest and the maximum load capacity is 0.655 wt % (Q3), accompanied by a slight decrease of the red emission intensity, which can be explained by the concentration quenching effect. Such a low saturated load capacity in the cationic ELM@neutral framework immobilization of [Ru]2+@1 is quite different from that of the neutral ELM@neutral framework immobilization of FRS@1 and the reported cationic ELM@anionic framework immobilizations and can be explained as strong electrostatic repulsion between the loaded [Ru]2+ ELMs while the neutral framework is not helpful in reducing the repulsion.

Luminescent Sensing of VOSs

Since 1, FRS@1, and (FRS+[Ru]2+)@1 composites are all stable in various VOSs, their sensing behaviors for various VOSs were investigated. Finely ground samples of them were dispersed in 10 common solvents (MeOH, EtOH, acetone, MeCN, ethyl acetate (EA), hexane, cyclohexane (Cyclo), DMF, DMA, and DMSO) and four aromatic solvents (benzene (Ben), fluorobenzene (F-Ben), chlorobenzene (Cl-Ben), and bromobenzene (Br-Ben)) to form emulsions for luminescence studies. As shown in , both the peak shifts and the intensities of 1 in the emission spectra excited at 365 nm are dependent on the solvent. In comparison with that in the solid state, the peak in MeOH is slightly red shifted (457 nm). In contrast, the peaks in all other solvents are more or less blue shifted, particularly for Br-Ben, which exhibits the largest red-shifted value (∼14 nm). From an intensity point of view, three solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and DMSO) show outstanding enhancement effects, while hexane exhibits the most significant quenching effect. However, under 365 nm UV light illumination, only the hexane suspension has an obviously darkened luminescence and can be clearly differentiated by the naked eye, as shown in c.
